definitions.definition: to carefully examine the facts of a situation, an event, a crime, etc. to find out the truth about it or how it happened
definitions.labels: (informal)(British English)(North American English)(British English)(North American English)(especially British English)(especially British English)(especially North American English)(especially British English)

examples.text: The FBI has been called in to investigate.
‘What was that noise?’ ‘I'll go and investigate.’
Detectives are currently investigating possible links between the murders.
The allegations have not yet been **thoroughly investigated**.
The report calls for a commission to **investigate the matter** further.
The case will be investigated in detail to determine whether the claims are true.
The company has pledged to investigate claims that its products are unsafe.
The company said it will investigate any customer complaints.

definitions.definition: to try to find out information about somebody’s character, activities, etc.
definitions.sensetop: investigate somebody for somethinginvestigate somebody over somethinginvestigate somebody

examples.text: This is not the first time he has been investigated by the police for fraud.
She is being investigated over allegations of illegal business dealings.
They were **investigated on suspicion of** drug smuggling.

definitions.definition: to find out information and facts about a subject or problem by study or research

examples.text: The study **investigates the effects** of feeding a high-energy diet to cows.
Researchers are investigating how foreign speakers gain fluency.

wordOrigin: early 16th cent.: from Latin investigat- ‘traced out’, from the verb investigare, from in- ‘into’ + vestigare ‘track, trace out’.
